A quick copy of the POD for the POD doc perlpod. =for comment This document is in Pod format. To read this, use a Pod formatter, like "perldoc perlpod". =head1 NAME X X perlpod - the Plain Old Documentation format =head1 DESCRIPTION Pod is a simple-to-use markup language used for writing documentation for Perl, Perl programs, and Perl modules. Translators are available for converting Pod to various formats like plain text, HTML, man pages, and more. Pod markup consists of three basic kinds of paragraphs: L, L, and L. =head2 Ordinary Paragraph X Most paragraphs in your documentation will be ordinary blocks of text, like this one. You can simply type in your text without any markup whatsoever, and with just a blank line before and after. When it gets formatted, it will undergo minimal formatting, like being rewrapped, probably put into a proportionally spaced font, and maybe even justified. You can use formatting codes in ordinary paragraphs, for B, I, C, L, and more. Such codes are explained in the "L" section, below. =head2 Verbatim Paragraph X X Verbatim paragraphs are usually used for presenting a codeblock or other text which does not require any special parsing or formatting, and which shouldn't be wrapped. A verbatim paragraph is distinguished by having its first character be a space or a tab. (And commonly, all its lines begin with spaces and/or tabs.) It should be reproduced exactly, with tabs assumed to be on 8-column boundaries. There are no special formatting codes, so you can't italicize or anything like that. A \ means \, and nothing else. =head2 Command Paragraph X A command paragraph is used for special treatment of whole chunks of text, usually as headings or parts of lists. All command paragraphs (which are typically only one line long) start with "=", followed by an identifier, followed by arbitrary text that the command can use however it pleases. Currently recognized commands are =pod =head1 Heading Text =head2 Heading Text =head3 Heading Text =head4 Heading Text =over indentlevel =item stuff =back =begin format =end format =for format text... =encoding type =cut To explain them each in detail: =over =item C<=head1 I> X<=head1> X<=head2> X<=head3> X<=head4> X X X X =item C<=head2 I> =item C<=head3 I> =item C<=head4 I> Head1 through head4 produce headings, head1 being the highest level. The text in the rest of this paragraph is the content of the heading. For example: =head2 Object Attributes The text "Object Attributes" comprises the heading there. (Note that head3 and head4 are recent additions, not supported in older Pod translators.) The text in these heading commands can use formatting codes, as seen here: =head2 Possible Values for C<$/> Such commands are explained in the "L" section, below. =item C<=over I> X<=over> X<=item> X<=back> X X X =item C<=item I> =item C<=back> Item, over, and back require a little more explanation: "=over" starts a region specifically for the generation of a list using "=item" commands, or for indenting (groups of) normal paragraphs. At the end of your list, use "=back" to end it. The I option to "=over" indicates how far over to indent, generally in ems (where one em is the width of an "M" in the document's base font) or roughly comparable units; if there is no I option, it defaults to four. (And some formatters may just ignore whatever I you provide.) In the I in C<=item I>, you may use formatting codes, as seen here: =item Using C<$|> to Control Buffering Such commands are explained in the "L" section, below. Note also that there are some basic rules to using "=over" ... "=back" regions: =over =item * Don't use "=item"s outside of an "=over" ... "=back" region. =item * The first thing after the "=over" command should be an "=item", unless there aren't going to be any items at all in this "=over" ... "=back" region. =item * Don't put "=headI" commands inside an "=over" ... "=back" region. =item * And perhaps most importantly, keep the items consistent: either use "=item *" for all of them, to produce bullets; or use "=item 1.", "=item 2.", etc., to produce numbered lists; or use "=item foo", "=item bar", etc. -- namely, things that look nothing like bullets or numbers. If you start with bullets or numbers, stick with them, as formatters use the first "=item" type to decide how to format the list. =back =item C<=cut> X<=cut> X To end a Pod block, use a blank line, then a line beginning with "=cut", and a blank line after it. This lets Perl (and the Pod formatter) know that this is where Perl code is resuming. (The blank line before the "=cut" is not technically necessary, but many older Pod processors require it.) =item C<=pod> X<=pod> X The "=pod" command by itself doesn't do much of anything, but it signals to Perl (and Pod formatters) that a Pod block starts here. A Pod block starts with I command paragraph, so a "=pod" command is usually used just when you want to start a Pod block with an ordinary paragraph or a verbatim paragraph. For example: =item stuff() This function does stuff. =cut sub stuff { ... } =pod Remember to check its return value, as in: stuff() || die "Couldn't do stuff!"; =cut =item C<=begin I> X<=begin> X<=end> X<=for> X X X =item C<=end I> =item C<=for I I> For, begin, and end will let you have regions of text/code/data that are not generally interpreted as normal Pod text, but are passed directly to particular formatters, or are otherwise special. A formatter that can use that format will use the region, otherwise it will be completely ignored. A command "=begin I", some paragraphs, and a command "=end I", mean that the text/data in between is meant for formatters that understand the special format called I. For example, =begin html

This is a raw HTML paragraph

=end html The command "=for I I" specifies that the remainder of just this paragraph (starting right after I) is in that special format. =for html

This is a raw HTML paragraph

This means the same thing as the above "=begin html" ... "=end html" region. That is, with "=for", you can have only one paragraph's worth of text (i.e., the text in "=foo targetname text..."), but with "=begin targetname" ... "=end targetname", you can have any amount of stuff inbetween. (Note that there still must be a blank line after the "=begin" command and a blank line before the "=end" command. Here are some examples of how to use these: =begin html
Figure 1.

=end html =begin text --------------- | foo | | bar | --------------- ^^^^ Figure 1. ^^^^ =end text Some format names that formatters currently are known to accept include "roff", "man", "latex", "tex", "text", and "html". (Some formatters will treat some of these as synonyms.) A format name of "comment" is common for just making notes (presumably to yourself) that won't appear in any formatted version of the Pod document: =for comment Make sure that all the available options are documented! Some I will require a leading colon (as in C<"=for :formatname">, or C<"=begin :formatname" ... "=end :formatname">), to signal that the text is not raw data, but instead I Pod text (i.e., possibly containing formatting codes) that's just not for normal formatting (e.g., may not be a normal-use paragraph, but might be for formatting as a footnote). =item C<=encoding I> X<=encoding> X This command is used for declaring the encoding of a document. Most users won't need this; but if your encoding isn't US-ASCII or Latin-1, then put a C<=encoding I> command early in the document so that pod formatters will know how to decode the document. For I, use a name recognized by the L module. Examples: =encoding utf8 =encoding koi8-r =encoding ShiftJIS =encoding big5 =back And don't forget, when using any command, that the command lasts up until the end of its I, not its line. So in the examples below, you can see that every command needs the blank line after it, to end its paragraph. Some examples of lists include: =over =item * First item =item * Second item =back =over =item Foo() Description of Foo function =item Bar() Description of Bar function =back =head2 Formatting Codes X X X X In ordinary paragraphs and in some command paragraphs, various formatting codes (a.k.a. "interior sequences") can be used: =for comment "interior sequences" is such an opaque term. Prefer "formatting codes" instead. =over =item CtextE> -- italic text X X<< IZ<><> >> X X Used for emphasis ("Ccareful!E>") and parameters ("CLABELE>") =item CtextE> -- bold text X X<< BZ<><> >> X X Used for switches ("C-nE switch>"), programs ("CchfnE for that>"), emphasis ("Ccareful!E>"), and so on ("CautovivificationE>"). =item CcodeE> -- code text X X<< CZ<><> >> X X Renders code in a typewriter font, or gives some other indication that this represents program text ("Cgmtime($^T)E>") or some other form of computerese ("Cdrwxr-xr-xE>"). =item CnameE> -- a hyperlink X X<< LZ<><> >> X X There are various syntaxes, listed below. In the syntaxes given, C, C, and C
cannot contain the characters '/' and '|'; and any '<' or '>' should be matched. =over =item * CnameE> Link to a Perl manual page (e.g., CNet::PingE>). Note that C should not contain spaces. This syntax is also occasionally used for references to UNIX man pages, as in Ccrontab(5)E>. =item * Cname/"sec"E> or Cname/secE> Link to a section in other manual page. E.g., Cperlsyn/"For Loops"E> =item * C/"sec"E> or C/secE> or C"sec"E> Link to a section in this manual page. E.g., C/"Object Methods"E> =back A section is started by the named heading or item. For example, Cperlvar/$.E> or Cperlvar/"$."E> both link to the section started by "C<=item $.>" in perlvar. And Cperlsyn/For LoopsE> or Cperlsyn/"For Loops"E> both link to the section started by "C<=head2 For Loops>" in perlsyn. To control what text is used for display, you use "Ctext|...E>", as in: =over =item * Ctext|nameE> Link this text to that manual page. E.g., CPerl Error Messages|perldiagE> =item * Ctext|name/"sec"E> or Ctext|name/secE> Link this text to that section in that manual page. E.g., Cpostfix "if"|perlsyn/"Statement Modifiers"E> =item * Ctext|/"sec"E> or Ctext|/secE> or Ctext|"sec"E> Link this text to that section in this manual page. E.g., Cthe various attributes|/"Member Data"E> =back Or you can link to a web page: =over =item * Cscheme:...E> Links to an absolute URL. For example, Chttp://www.perl.org/E>. But note that there is no corresponding Ctext|scheme:...E> syntax, for various reasons. =back =item CescapeE> -- a character escape X X<< EZ<><> >> X X Very similar to HTML/XML C<&I;> "entity references": =over =item * CltE> -- a literal E (less than) =item * CgtE> -- a literal E (greater than) =item * CverbarE> -- a literal | (Itical I) =item * CsolE> = a literal / (Iidus) The above four are optional except in other formatting codes, notably C...E>, and when preceded by a capital letter. =item * ChtmlnameE> Some non-numeric HTML entity name, such as CeacuteE>, meaning the same thing as C<é> in HTML -- i.e., a lowercase e with an acute (/-shaped) accent. =item * CnumberE> The ASCII/Latin-1/Unicode character with that number. A leading "0x" means that I is hex, as in C0x201EE>. A leading "0" means that I is octal, as in C075E>. Otherwise I is interpreted as being in decimal, as in C181E>. Note that older Pod formatters might not recognize octal or hex numeric escapes, and that many formatters cannot reliably render characters above 255. (Some formatters may even have to use compromised renderings of Latin-1 characters, like rendering CeacuteE> as just a plain "e".) =back =item CfilenameE> -- used for filenames X X<< FZ<><> >> X X Typically displayed in italics. Example: "C.cshrcE>" =item CtextE> -- text contains non-breaking spaces X X<< SZ<><> >> X X This means that the words in I should not be broken across lines. Example: S$x ? $y : $zE>>. =item Ctopic nameE> -- an index entry X X<< XZ<><> >> X X This is ignored by most formatters, but some may use it for building indexes. It always renders as empty-string. Example: Cabsolutizing relative URLsE> =item CE> -- a null (zero-effect) formatting code X X<< ZZ<><> >> X X This is rarely used. It's one way to get around using an EE...E code sometimes. For example, instead of "CltE3>" (for "NE3") you could write "CEE3>" (the "ZEE" breaks up the "N" and the "E" so they can't be considered the part of a (fictitious) "NE...E" code. =for comment This was formerly explained as a "zero-width character". But it in most parser models, it parses to nothing at all, as opposed to parsing as if it were a E or E, which are REAL zero-width characters. So "width" and "character" are exactly the wrong words. =back Most of the time, you will need only a single set of angle brackets to delimit the beginning and end of formatting codes. However, sometimes you will want to put a real right angle bracket (a greater-than sign, '>') inside of a formatting code. This is particularly common when using a formatting code to provide a different font-type for a snippet of code. As with all things in Perl, there is more than one way to do it. One way is to simply escape the closing bracket using an C code: C<$a E=E $b> This will produce: "C<$a E=E $b>" A more readable, and perhaps more "plain" way is to use an alternate set of delimiters that doesn't require a single ">" to be escaped. With the Pod formatters that are standard starting with perl5.5.660, doubled angle brackets ("<<" and ">>") may be used I For example, the following will do the trick: X C<< $a <=> $b >> In fact, you can use as many repeated angle-brackets as you like so long as you have the same number of them in the opening and closing delimiters, and make sure that whitespace immediately follows the last '<' of the opening delimiter, and immediately precedes the first '>' of the closing delimiter. (The whitespace is ignored.) So the following will also work: X C<<< $a <=> $b >>> C<<<< $a <=> $b >>>> And they all mean exactly the same as this: C<$a E=E $b> As a further example, this means that if you wanted to put these bits of code in C (code) style: open(X, ">>thing.dat") || die $! $foo->bar(); you could do it like so: C<<< open(X, ">>thing.dat") || die $! >>> C<< $foo->bar(); >> which is presumably easier to read than the old way: CEthing.dat") || die $!> C<$foo-Ebar();> This is currently supported by pod2text (Pod::Text), pod2man (Pod::Man), and any other pod2xxx or Pod::Xxxx translators that use Pod::Parser 1.093 or later, or Pod::Tree 1.02 or later. =head2 The Intent X The intent is simplicity of use, not power of expression. Paragraphs look like paragraphs (block format), so that they stand out visually, and so that I could run them through C easily to reformat them (that's F7 in my version of B, or Esc Q in my version of B). I wanted the translator to always leave the C<'> and C<`> and C<"> quotes alone, in verbatim mode, so I could slurp in a working program, shift it over four spaces, and have it print out, er, verbatim. And presumably in a monospace font. The Pod format is not necessarily sufficient for writing a book. Pod is just meant to be an idiot-proof common source for nroff, HTML, TeX, and other markup languages, as used for online documentation. Translators exist for B, B, B (that's for nroff(1) and troff(1)), B, and B. Various others are available in CPAN. =head2 Embedding Pods in Perl Modules X You can embed Pod documentation in your Perl modules and scripts. Start your documentation with an empty line, a "=head1" command at the beginning, and end it with a "=cut" command and an empty line. Perl will ignore the Pod text. See any of the supplied library modules for examples. If you're going to put your Pod at the end of the file, and you're using an __END__ or __DATA__ cut mark, make sure to put an empty line there before the first Pod command. __END__ =head1 NAME Time::Local - efficiently compute time from local and GMT time Without that empty line before the "=head1", many translators wouldn't have recognized the "=head1" as starting a Pod block. =head2 Hints for Writing Pod =over =item * X X The B command is provided for checking Pod syntax for errors and warnings. For example, it checks for completely blank lines in Pod blocks and for unknown commands and formatting codes. You should still also pass your document through one or more translators and proofread the result, or print out the result and proofread that. Some of the problems found may be bugs in the translators, which you may or may not wish to work around. =item * If you're more familiar with writing in HTML than with writing in Pod, you can try your hand at writing documentation in simple HTML, and converting it to Pod with the experimental L module, (available in CPAN), and looking at the resulting code. The experimental L module in CPAN might also be useful. =item * Many older Pod translators require the lines before every Pod command and after every Pod command (including "=cut"!) to be a blank line. Having something like this: # - - - - - - - - - - - - =item $firecracker->boom() This noisily detonates the firecracker object. =cut sub boom { ... ...will make such Pod translators completely fail to see the Pod block at all. Instead, have it like this: # - - - - - - - - - - - - =item $firecracker->boom() This noisily detonates the firecracker object. =cut sub boom { ... =item * Some older Pod translators require paragraphs (including command paragraphs like "=head2 Functions") to be separated by I empty lines. If you have an apparently empty line with some spaces on it, this might not count as a separator for those translators, and that could cause odd formatting. =item * Older translators might add wording around an LEE link, so that CFoo::BarE> may become "the Foo::Bar manpage", for example. So you shouldn't write things like CfooE documentation>, if you want the translated document to read sensibly -- instead write CFoo::Bar|Foo::BarE documentation> or Cthe Foo::Bar documentation|Foo::BarE>, to control how the link comes out. =item * Going past the 70th column in a verbatim block might be ungracefully wrapped by some formatters. =back =head1 SEE ALSO L, L, L, L, L, L, L. =head1 AUTHOR Larry Wall, Sean M. Burke =cut [[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Organic Chemistry/Acetone peroxide synthesis

revision.text: == [[Organic_Chemistry/Acetone_peroxide_synthesis]] == {| cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" style="border: 1px red solid; background: #ffffcc; width: 95%; margin: auto; color: #000000;" | style="width: 40px; text-align: center;" | [[Image:Stop hand nuvola.svg|30px]] | '''Closed''' per [[User:Ewen|Ewen]]'s suggestions of merged and then '''delete''' --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 13:11, 30 November 2006 (UTC) |- | colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px red dashed;" | I propose that this page should be '''deleted''' on the following grounds: *It is irrelevant to the textbook - there are countless other syntheses which are more important to consider for an undergraduate student (the book's target audience). *It is intended for domestic, unsupervised creation of an explosive material; one which has been/can be used for terrorist purposes. Such a synthesis is potentially homicidal and/or suicidal and certainly brings the wikibook project into disrepute. The issue has been discussed on the [[Talk:Organic_Chemistry/Acetone_peroxide_synthesis|Talk page for the article]]. [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 13:57, 13 November 2006 (UTC) :This issue has already come up, and despite my best efforts, I was unable to persuade other people in the community to delete this one. We do have a warning template somewhere that can be used to point out the danger of the module, and the sheer stupidity of actually following the instructions. I doubt, however, that we will be able to get this one deleted. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] ([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]]) 14:02, 13 November 2006 (UTC) *'''Comment''' -- (edit conflict) we've discussed this chapter before... we need a "survived VfD" template like wikipedia uses, though we'd probably need to adopt wikipedia's tranclusion method to make that work. --[[User:SBJohnny|'''SB_Johnny''']] | [[User talk:SBJohnny|talk]] 14:03, 13 November 2006 (UTC) :*'''Comment''' - you after this {{vfd-survived}} - deletion templates?! --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 14:06, 13 November 2006 (UTC) ::Sorry, I didn't realise that it had already been though the process. I still propose that it be deleted, though. How can I access the previous discussion of this article's 'merits'? [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 14:29, 13 November 2006 (UTC) :::The previous discussion centered mostly around censorship. People didn't think that wikibooks should exclude information only on the grounds that it poses a clear, immediate threat to anybody who ever reads it. Also, the fact that the article is written from a "do it yourself in your own kitchen while mom and dad are away" perspective, which poses an even greater risk to health and safety, only makes the article more "cool" and "dangerous", and therefore mandated that it be kept here on wikibooks. The previous discussion is likely somewhere in the archives, i'll try to dig up the link. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] ([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]]) 14:46, 13 November 2006 (UTC) :::Also, there had been a {{tl|Danger}} template on that page, but it appears to have been removed by an IP user. I have reinstated it. I dont think that template should be removed for any reason. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] ([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]]) 14:49, 13 November 2006 (UTC) OK, I've read the previous discussion. It's [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Chemical synthesis/Acetone peroxide|here]]. I'd like to bring some new facts to the debate: The synthesis is '''not''' part of any undergraduate course I am aware of, and it is '''not''' part of any undergraduate textbook I am aware of. I have checked, but there is always a chance that I am wrong. I await contradiction, but I would be surpised: I have studied and taught chemistry (at the level this wikibook is aimed towards) since 1985. I checked books with literally hundreds of syntheses, and those books implicitly rate those many syntheses as more important than the synthesis of acetone peroxide. The chemical concerned, and the methods involved in its preparation, have '''zero educational value'''. In fact, apart from its use in improvised explosive devices, the chemical has no value whatsoever. Again, I have checked, but there is always a chance that I am wrong. I await contradiction. Contrast this with 'Mathematics'; Yes, you can use maths to engineer nuclear weapons ''but you can also use maths for other purposes''. If wikibooks contributors wanted to alert the authorities about the availability of recipes for explosives, instead of writing a working method they could include a spoof method which claimed to be correct. It would make the same point at no risk. I would classify this article alongside '''pornography''', and treat it accordingly. Why does anyone ''need'' to know how to make this chemical? Why would anyone ''need'' to view porn? I would not include porn where it could be accessed inadvertently. Likewise this synthesis. This article should be '''deleted'''. Perhaps we should have a book clearly marked for lethally dangerous activities which people can access if they want, but with no risk that they read the article without being warned of its content first. This synthesis would find a place there. [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 16:08, 13 November 2006 (UTC) * I '''agree''' with Whiteknight and Ewen. This module is not necessary neither for the Organic Chemistry book nor for anyone studying chemistry and may serve criminal purposes. I think that in such situations we should choose te safest solution and remove the content that is doubtful. I don't agree that Wikibooks is a place where the freedom of speech is the most important principal. Where everything is allowed, chaos occurs, and I believe that quality, not quantity, is the thing we should take as our target. People in Commons are in similar situation: there are many graphics that have unclear copyrights. Decision in all cases is the same: such images are removed from Commons. I don't see any reason why we should behave different. --[[User:Derbeth|Derbeth]] [[User talk:Derbeth|talk]] 16:15, 13 November 2006 (UTC) : '''Comment''' If indeed the book holds no educational value, and is dangerous (I know nothing about chemestry myself...) then I feel it should be removed. I don't like the idea of spreading dangerous "do-it-yourself" tutorials, especially on a wiki. A smart vandal can cause great danger to the reader, more than usual. --[[User:Dragontamer|Dragontamer]] 18:06, 13 November 2006 (UTC) *'''delete''' - I'm with [[User:Dragontamer|Dragontamer]] - I know little but if people who do reckon it should be out - fine --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 18:24, 13 November 2006 (UTC) *'''Delete''' - Last time sockpuppets and Wikipedia users came over to cast their opinions on how to run our project and surprise, surprise, those users have done nothing here since those votes. Let's actually delete this thing now. The arguments for deleting it are not new and the reason it failed last time was because one user made a huge argument out of it. Time to use consensus and not 100% acceptance to get this done if it happens again. -[[User:Withinfocus|'''within''']][[User talk:Withinfocus|'''focus''']] 01:47, 15 November 2006 (UTC) *: Last time, arguments for non-censorship were put forth and not countered. Some users offering their views were indeed new to the project but views aren't votes (and consensus isn't a vote) and arguements against censorship weren't refuted. *: At least one of the Wikipedia users stayed on Wikibooks (more active here than there). Consensus is only reached after the debate is over. If arguments haven't been countered, the debate isn't over. *: Withinfocus, even a mere hint of an acusation of sockpuppetry weighs heavily on me. I'd like a formal apology. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] 11:37, 16 November 2006 (UTC) **:Arguments for non-censorship were significantly refuted and I think it was more of an issue of arguing just to argue about rights more than keeping the actual content alive. Seeing this page in its present state seems to push even more that the article is hurting the progress of the book and some of the book's own editors are bothered by it. Is its presence here truly helping the book and project as a whole? '''All''' of the votes I marked as being too new to be true opinions of members of the Wikibooks project have done no editing since that voting period; they were quick swoops into Wikibooks and I don't think that's fair to the project. Having some activity here and at least understanding productive book-writing are in my opinion essential to be a fully-weighted voter here, even though you pulled out the rule-book to cite that no explicit rules existed to stop their swoops. I decided to stop being part of that discussion because it would have continued on and on. A single user with continual follow-ups shouldn't block a decision. You are not the one accused of sockpuppetry, it is the four users I mentioned earlier, and so an apology will not be given, and I'm not really sure what formal would even mean in an online wiki. -[[User:Withinfocus|'''within''']][[User talk:Withinfocus|'''focus''']] 02:01, 17 November 2006 (UTC) *'''Clarification''' -- my vote is neutral... I gave my arguments for keeping last time, but will concede the point join any consensus. (see below...) --[[User:SBJohnny|'''SB_Johnny''']] | [[User talk:SBJohnny|talk]] 15:55, 16 November 2006 (UTC) *:'''Delete''' - As a contributor to this book, I think this synthesis has no business being in the book. It's an organic chemistry textbook, not an organic synthesis textbook, let alone an explosives synthesis textbook. If someone wants to write a book on the synthesis of explosives, I have no opposition to that, but I think having that single synthesis in the book is out of place, it detracts from the legitimacy of the text by making it seem more like an Anarchists Cookbook kind of text, and to be honest, if remains attached to the organic chemistry textbook, I'm going to have to stop contributing. I don't mean that as any sort of threat, since it has little weight based on how new I am. It's simply that I don't want to be associated with a text like that. -- [[User:Pdavis68|Pete]] 19:59, 16 November 2006 (UTC) Swift proposes keeping this page because to delete it from 'Organic chemistry' would be censorship. (Do correct me if I'm misrepresenting you, Swift...) Whether removing the page from this book is censorship or not, its removal is a very good idea because: #The article is available elsewhere, so its removal from this place does not cause a loss of information. #The context of the 'Organic chemistry' textbook creates the possibility that people will come across the article and believe it to be a useful and important part of their organic chemistry education. Some younger readers may even attempt the synthesis because they are young and irresponsible. (NB I don't assume that all youngsters are irresponsible, or that everyone older is 'mature' in their behaviour, but legally there are ages which are taken as the threshhold of responsibility, and this text is aimed at students who may be below that age.) Accessing this material could in some companies, colleges and universities prove to be such a serious breach of IT policy that users are dismissed, when in fact they accessed the material in good faith. Some nefarious users may defend their possession of this method on the grounds that it was included in an otherwise innocent book, when in fact they intend to use it to murder. #Teachers will find it impossible to recommend this otherwise-valuable resource if it contains this page. So, if removing this article is censorship, then censorship is a good idea. Call it what you want, it doesn't matter. Please delete this article from 'Organic chemistry'. [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 20:29, 16 November 2006 (UTC) (BTW: Swift, your previous vote is no longer included ;-) Are you still in favour of keeping the Acetone peroxide synthesis as part of 'Organic chemistry' ''and'' 'Chemical synthesis' or would you accept it as part of 'Chemical synthesis' alone?) [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 20:32, 16 November 2006 (UTC) : OK, it seems you aren't so much wanting the page deleted from Wikibooks as you want it out of [[Organic Chemistry]]. If this is the case, I'll gladly '''move''' it to [[Chemical synthesis]] as previously suggested. : If not, my vote is '''strong keep''' which I'll elaborate on if needed. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] 22:05, 16 November 2006 (UTC) :: Are we agreed then? Delete Organic chemistry/Acetone peroxide synthesis and keep Chemical synthesis/Acetone peroxide synthesis? I'd be happy for that to happen. [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 22:48, 16 November 2006 (UTC) ::: Yes, but give me time to merge the two into the CS book. I'll get it done in the next few days. Just remove links to the page from OC and this will be over in a few days if no-one objects. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] 01:15, 17 November 2006 (UTC) :::: '''Comment:''' Ewen has started editing on the CS book and I've stayed back to avoid what I think would only result in conflict. I don't think there is any hurry. I'm going to wait till Ewen and I sort out our differences or he backs away from the relevant book pages. :::: '''Do not delete before then.''' --[[User:Swift|Swift]] 16:45, 17 November 2006 (UTC) :::Once you complete this action (if no one objects), then we should start another VfD for the entire Chemical Synthesis book since it seems many users voting here are worried about its content. Another censorship argument might explode, but with a single user pushing that topic a consensus to delete might still be achieved past that single user. -[[User:Withinfocus|'''within''']][[User talk:Withinfocus|'''focus''']] 02:12, 17 November 2006 (UTC) ::::I would probably vote against deleting the [[Chemical synthesis]] book. We are not in the business of censoring content, and there is no citable policy that would warrant the deletion of that book, controversial as it may be. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] ([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]]) :::::This is going to open the flood gates, but perhaps some outside "official" opinion from the Wikimedia bigwigs needs to address this. I believe that such books violate public responsibility and I would think some sort of legal response is needed. Housing books that can show how to make bombs could jeopardize the whole project. Since there might be more that one strong proponent for non-censorship (even though I think that can be a misleading term) based on this comment, I wouldn't want to go forward with the VfD until a policy is created or a consultation takes place. I assumed a VfD would succeed with a single dissenter but if you and others climb on this could last way too long. -[[User:Withinfocus|'''within''']][[User talk:Withinfocus|'''focus''']] 02:57, 17 November 2006 (UTC) ::::::I'll throw my $0.02 into this. I'd probably vote against a delete. First of all, there are so many web sites and documents on eMule on how to synthesize just about anything that really, this is all pretty easy to obtain information. Anyone who wants to make a bomb is going to easily find out how. It's as simple as that. You don't need to be a chemist, you don't need to have fancy equipment or hard to get materials. Most homes have all the necessary ingredients lying around to make at least a moderately powerful bomb. So, I have no problem with there being a wikibook that contain that. ::::::That said, I would expect a book called Chemical Synthesis to have a lot more than just explosives. If that's all you want to have in it, then call it what it is: Chemistry of Explosives. I'm just a firm believer in "truth in advertising" and that you should call a spade a spade. But I have no moral objections to it. I've had the know how and the ability to make drugs, explosives, and so forth, since I was in high school, back when doing that kind of stuff interested me. But the fact is, 99% of the readers, like me, aren't going to have the motivation to actually do it, because a lot of them are a lot of work to do right. Of that 1% that do, about 60% are going to go blow up a tree trunk or something. 35% are going to blow themselves up (and that's okay, because that's what evolution is all about), and maybe 5% will actually do something bad with it, but if they didn't get the info from this book, they'd get it somewhere else, because clearly they're motivated. Anyway, that's my $0.02. I'd vote to keep it. Hell, I'll probably read through it, just out of curiousity, and to be honest, for an organic chemist, there's good techniques to be learned that are applicable to other stuff. -- [[User:Pdavis68|Pete]] 03:25, 17 November 2006 (UTC) ::::::Just wanted to add one more note. I'm setting up a lab in a work room behind my garage. The #1 concern I have is making sure I don't blow up the work room and garage by accident. One of the primary chemicals involved in explosives is Nitric Acid. Nitric acid is also used in a great number of perfectly legitimate organic chemistry. In fact, it's practically a must-have. My biggest concern is making my lab safe for nitric acid so I don't blow the place up. So really, anyone who can get their hands on it, can make explosives by accident. The advantage of a book with this information is that it's going to have a lot of safety tips for dealing with Nitric Acid, or at least, I assume it will. -- [[User:Pdavis68|Pete]] 03:33, 17 November 2006 (UTC) ::::::There is a difference between deleting a single errant page, and an entire book, especially if the deletions are performed in a policy grey-area. But don't misunderstand me, i'm neither pro nor contra censorship (at least not noticably). The issue of censorship therefore is not important to me whatsoever. What is important to me, however, is the wikibooks project. I would like to see a few things: (a) the wikibooks project is safe, secure, and stable, (b) the members here are happy (and by extension, prolific), (c) the materials we produce are high quality, or are improving in quality. Deleting the page from the [[Organic Chemistry]] book certainly helps with point (c), by making the [[Organic Chemistry]] book higher quality. However, deleting the [[Chemical Synthesis]] will hurt point (b) without necessarily helping either of the other points, and I see that as a net loss for the project. Now, if the [[Chemical Synthesis]] book was against policy, or it posed a distinct threat to the project (legal threat, etc), the importance of maintaining point (a) would trump the hurt feelings of point (b). Until I know that the book poses such a threat, however, i won't vote to delete it. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] ([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]]) 17:27, 17 November 2006 (UTC) :::::::So what is the proper direction to take this then? Does anyone know of who to contact regarding the legalities of this situation? I think being appropriate overrules being happy, and if my book had inappropriate areas that I personally enjoyed I would still remove them because their presence is controversial. Like Derbeth said, I wouldn't use Wikibooks as a platform for free speech because I think high-quality, appropriate book-writing is the real goal. Chemical synthesis seems to be there for controversy and fun, not so much being a good book. -[[User:Withinfocus|'''within''']][[User talk:Withinfocus|'''focus''']] 22:06, 17 November 2006 (UTC) :::::::: "''Chemical synthesis seems to be there for controversy and fun''". Withinfocus, this is precisely why we have [[WB:AGF]]. You make an assumption based on prejudice, not on knowledge, and make no attempt to approach the "other side" and understand their viewpoint. This, not the content, is what makes the discussion so heated and difficult to solve. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] 11:06, 21 November 2006 (UTC) :::::::::Please, please do not continue to tell '''me''' what '''I''' am saying. I and any other user here are entitled to opinions, and besides that an opinion was stated I do believe it to have a strong basis here. [[WB:AGF]], although not an actual policy or guideline, is about intentions and I see those intentions as malicious. The book is in quite a poor state which is understandable and I would fully support its quality improvement, but the book is almost entirely based on making extremely dangerous chemicals and has not changed in some time to refute that association. I '''know''' that there is a large percentage of the main page covered in bright red warning type and almost every page has a huge disclaimer on it. The "other" viewpoint was established several months ago and I stopped being a part of that discussion, yet I see little to no positive improvement for making this a book about overall chemical synthesis and less about explosive chemical synthesis. When a work is in jeopardy, I would want it tended to by those who support it. The conversation switched to discussing the legal issues with housing this content, yet you are pulling it back and thus I will not make further response on that front and will only discuss what I intended to. Wikimedia legal people can officially decide if the book can be housed here, labeled as controversial or not. -[[User:Withinfocus|'''within''']][[User talk:Withinfocus|'''focus''']] 23:56, 22 November 2006 (UTC) *'''Delete''' "Censorship"? Really now, it's GPL information. If you want to copy it and put it somewhere else to "save it," by all means, do so. I don't think the reason we should delete it is ''because explosives are bad''. I think whether we want explosive-making instructions on this site is another question entirely. The reason we should delete this is because synthesizing explosives isn't that relevant to organic chemistry. Really, have you ever gone to an organic chemistry course and have your professor show you that? Organic chemistry is centrally about the chemistry of living things - that involved within biological creatures. Organic chemistry is not about learning ways to 'bring down the man.' If you want this knowledge to spread, go ahead and copy it. But it doesn't belong over here in this book, because outside of the 'chemistry' word, it really has nothing to do with the textbook's subject. In other words, it's not being censored, so stop whining. You have every right to share this knowledge. You just don't have the right to force others to cram this knowledge in a place it doesn't belong, just because you want more people to see it. Censorship is when the flow of an idea is prevented. I could care less whether this idea goes around or not, but it's not the job of an organic chemistry to teach people how to build explosives. -[[User:Monk|Monk]] 19:16, 18 November 2006 (UTC) *'''Hold''' -- consider my vote '''keep''' until this is sorted out. --[[User:SBJohnny|'''SB_Johnny''']] | [[User talk:SBJohnny|talk]] 13:27, 18 November 2006 (UTC) *'''Information''' - Swift has moved this controversial page to Chemical Synthesis, where I believe it belongs and it is now out of the Organic Chemistry textbook. My concern was largely with the quality of the Organic Chemistry textbook and so I am happy. :Whiteknight and others have a more general concern about the quality of wikibooks in general and I too share that concern. Swift has made clear (though possibly not here, but I have read some comments from him in various places), that the Chemical Syntehsis book is intended to contain a lot more entries than simply the explosives currently contained. His reasoning for the existing synthesis examples, to my understanding (Swift, correct me if I'm wrong), is that these pages were removed from Wikipedia. I am personally satisfied by this explanation and I don't think any timetable need be enforced on how soon non-explosives entries need to be added to the Chemical Synthesis text. :I hope to get involved in that text at some point and it's unlikely that any of the synthesis examples I give will have anything to do with explosives. But I don't expect to get to it until possibly mid-2007 as I have my hands full with the organic chemistry textbook. But I am satisfied that the synthesis book can serve as more than an anarchist cookbook and be a serious, valuable source. Just, like many other books here, it will require a lot of work. If there's a separate vote to delete that book, I will likely vote against deletion unless I see a compelling argument for deletion and, at this point, I haven't seen such an argument. -- [[User:Pdavis68|Pete]] 19:48, 18 November 2006 (UTC) :: "''correct me if I'm wrong ... these pages were removed from Wikipedia.''" Partly, as some were already here. :: Those that I found here were of the anarchist-cookbook-type. It didn't bother me since I know well from Wikipedia that content doesn't get added by importance, but interest and excitment (think [[w:Jenna Jameson]] vs. [[w:Andrew Wiles]] -- guess which has the longer article). :: Those copied from Wikipedia were done so because, in effect being instruction manuals, they lay [[w:WP:WIW#Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information|outside the scope of the project]]. My involvement came through the [[w:Nitroglycerin]] article where it was deceided the content should be moved elsewhere. I found a collection of controversial syntheses and moved all of them here (the respective WP articles link to us via the {{wikibooks}} template). I would not be the least bit surprised if Wikipedia still had other synthases which no-one has bothered over, just as the countless food and drink recipes go unnoticed (I've recently alerted the WP Cocktail project of WB as they had a lot of these). It would certainly be a good idea to browse Wikipedia and see if it has content that belongs in the [[Chemical synthesis]] book, but I haven't gotten around to that. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] 11:06, 21 November 2006 (UTC) I have edited the Organic Chemistry and Chemical Synthesis versions of the recipes to (a) replace domestic chemicals with lab chemicals and (b) reduce quantities to give safer yields. I'll not be editing these any more so if Swift wants to get on with merging the Acetone Peroxide synthesis to make one article under Chemical synthesis then please do... [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 13:26, 21 November 2006 (UTC) * It would ''appear'' to me that this one has been resolved as a keep/merge decision. I suggest if there are no other views expressed in the next 5 days it is closed as such --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 13:12, 25 November 2006 (UTC) I have merged the content of [[Organic Chemistry/Acetone peroxide synthesis]] with [[Chemical synthesis/Acetone peroxide]]. Can the 'Organic Chemistry' version now be deleted and the 'Chemical synthesis' one kept? [[User:Ewen|Ewen]] 14:35, 25 November 2006 (UTC) |}

revision.text: == [[X-Plane]] == {| cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" style="border: 1px red solid; background: #ffffcc; width: 95%; margin: auto; color: #000000;" | style="width: 40px; text-align: center;" | [[Image:Stop hand nuvola.svg|30px]] | '''Delete''' --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 13:04, 27 November 2006 (UTC) |- | colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px red dashed;" | Looks like a game guide, and I've transwikied it to [[StrategyWiki:X-Plane]]. --[[User:MrDrBob|DrBob]] 14:30, 11 November 2006 (UTC) : '''Comment''' I realize the current trend is to transwiki games guides to StrategyWiki, but the authors are being informed of this, right? I just wanna make sure. Even when the marijuana book was deleted, we attempted to contact the authors. --[[User:Dragontamer|Dragontamer]] 21:19, 11 November 2006 (UTC) ::It's been my understanding, typically, that the authors are the ones moving the material to strategy wiki. If that's not the case, we still do offer redirects. --[[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] ([[User talk:Whiteknight|talk]]) ([[User:Whiteknight/Proposed Books|projects]]) 13:36, 14 November 2006 (UTC) : '''Delete now that it's transwikied.''' -[[User:Monk|Monk]] 19:04, 18 November 2006 (UTC) : '''Delete''' --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] 04:47, 19 November 2006 (UTC) |}

== NAME == perlpod - the Plain Old Documentation format == DESCRIPTION == Pod is a simple-to-use markup language used for writing documentation for Perl, Perl programs, and Perl modules. Translators are available for converting Pod to various formats like plain text, HTML, man pages, and more. Pod markup consists of three basic kinds of paragraphs: * [[ordinary|Ordinary Paragraph]] * [[verbatim|Verbatim Paragraph]], and * [[command|Command Paragraph]]. === Ordinary Paragraph === Most paragraphs in your documentation will be ordinary blocks of text, like this one. You can simply type in your text without any markup whatsoever, and with just a blank line before and after. When it gets formatted, it will undergo minimal formatting, like being rewrapped, probably put into a proportionally spaced font, and maybe even justified. You can use formatting codes in ordinary paragraphs, for '''bold''', ''italic'', code-style, [[perlfaq|hyperlinks]], and more. Such codes are explained in the [[Formatting Codes]] section, below. === Verbatim Paragraph === Verbatim paragraphs are usually used for presenting a codeblock or other text which does not require any special parsing or formatting, and which shouldn't be wrapped. A verbatim paragraph is distinguished by having its first character be a space or a tab. (And commonly, all its lines begin with spaces and/or tabs.) It should be reproduced exactly, with tabs assumed to be on 8-column boundaries. There are no special formatting codes, so you can't italicize or anything like that. A \ means \, and nothing else. === Command Paragraph === A command paragraph is used for special treatment of whole chunks of text, usually as headings or parts of lists. All command paragraphs (which are typically only one line long) start with "=", followed by an identifier, followed by arbitrary text that the command can use however it pleases. Currently recognized commands are =pod =head1 Heading Text =head2 Heading Text =head3 Heading Text =head4 Heading Text =over indentlevel =item stuff =back =begin format =end format =for format text... =encoding type =cut To explain them each in detail: : =head1 Heading Text : =head2 Heading Text : =head3 Heading Text : =head4 Heading Text Head1 through head4 produce headings, head1 being the highest level. The text in the rest of this paragraph is the content of the heading. For example: : =head2 Object Attributes The text "Object Attributes" comprises the heading there. (Note that head3 and head4 are recent additions, not supported in older Pod translators.) The text in these heading commands can use formatting codes, as seen here: : =head2 Possible Values for C<$/> Such commands are explained in the [[Formatting Codes|Formatting Codes]] section, below. : =over indentlevel : =item stuff... : =back Item, over, and back require a little more explanation: "=over" starts a region specifically for the generation of a list using "=item" commands, or for indenting (groups of) normal paragraphs. At the end of your list, use "=back" to end it. The I option to "=over" indicates how far over to indent, generally in ems (where one em is the width of an "M" in the document's base font) or roughly comparable units; if there is no I option, it defaults to four. (And some formatters may just ignore whatever you provide.) In the I in C<=item I>, you may use formatting codes, as seen here: : =item Using $| to Control Buffering Such commands are explained in the "L" section, below. Note also that there are some basic rules to using "=over" ... "=back" regions: :* Don't use "=item"s outside of an "=over" ... "=back" region. :* The first thing after the "=over" command should be an "=item", unless there aren't going to be any items at all in this "=over" ... "=back" region. :* Don't put "=headI" commands inside an "=over" ... "=back" region. :* And perhaps most importantly, keep the items consistent: either use "=item *" for all of them, to produce bullets; or use "=item 1.", "=item 2.", etc., to produce numbered lists; or use "=item foo", "=item bar", etc. -- namely, things that look nothing like bullets or numbers. :If you start with bullets or numbers, stick with them, as formatters use the first "=item" type to decide how to format the list. : =cut To end a Pod block, use a blank line, then a line beginning with "=cut", and a blank line after it. This lets Perl (and the Pod formatter) know that this is where Perl code is resuming. (The blank line before the "=cut" is not technically necessary, but many older Pod processors require it.) : =pod The "=pod" command by itself doesn't do much of anything, but it signals to Perl (and Pod formatters) that a Pod block starts here. A Pod block starts with I command paragraph, so a "=pod" command is usually used just when you want to start a Pod block with an ordinary paragraph or a verbatim paragraph. For example: =item stuff() This function does stuff. =cut sub stuff { ... } =pod Remember to check its return value, as in: stuff() || die "Couldn't do stuff!"; =cut * =begin formatname * =end formatname * =for formatname text... For, begin, and end will let you have regions of text/code/data that are not generally interpreted as normal Pod text, but are passed directly to particular formatters, or are otherwise special. A formatter that can use that format will use the region, otherwise it will be completely ignored. A command "=begin I", some paragraphs, and a command "=end I", mean that the text/data in between is meant for formatters that understand the special format called I. For example, =begin html

This is a raw HTML paragraph

=end html The command "=for I I" specifies that the remainder of just this paragraph (starting right after I) is in that special format. =for html

This is a raw HTML paragraph

This means the same thing as the above "=begin html" ... "=end html" region. That is, with "=for", you can have only one paragraph's worth of text (i.e., the text in "=foo targetname text..."), but with "=begin targetname" ... "=end targetname", you can have any amount of stuff inbetween. (Note that there still must be a blank line after the "=begin" command and a blank line before the "=end" command. Here are some examples of how to use these: =begin html
Figure 1.

=end html =begin text --------------- | foo | | bar | --------------- ^^^^ Figure 1. ^^^^ =end text Some format names that formatters currently are known to accept include "roff", "man", "latex", "tex", "text", and "html". (Some formatters will treat some of these as synonyms.) A format name of "comment" is common for just making notes (presumably to yourself) that won't appear in any formatted version of the Pod document: =for comment Make sure that all the available options are documented! Some I will require a leading colon (as in C<"=for :formatname">, or C<"=begin :formatname" ... "=end :formatname">), to signal that the text is not raw data, but instead I Pod text (i.e., possibly containing formatting codes) that's just not for normal formatting (e.g., may not be a normal-use paragraph, but might be for formatting as a footnote). * =encoding encodingname This command is used for declaring the encoding of a document. Most users won't need this; but if your encoding isn't US-ASCII or Latin-1, then put a C<=encoding I> command early in the document so that pod formatters will know how to decode the document. For I, use a name recognized by the L module. Examples: =encoding utf8 =encoding koi8-r =encoding ShiftJIS =encoding big5 And don't forget, when using any command, that the command lasts up until the end of its I, not its line. So in the examples below, you can see that every command needs the blank line after it, to end its paragraph. Some examples of lists include: =over =item * First item =item * Second item =back =over =item Foo() Description of Foo function =item Bar() Description of Bar function =back === Formatting Codes === In ordinary paragraphs and in some command paragraphs, various formatting codes (a.k.a. "interior sequences") can be used: ; I : italic text : Used for emphasis ("C>") and parameters ("C>") ; B : bold text : Used for switches ("C switch>"), programs ("C for that>"), emphasis ("C>"), and so on ("C>"). ; C : code text : Renders code in a typewriter font, or gives some other indication that this represents program text "C" or some other form of computerese "C". ; L : a hyperlink : There are various syntaxes, listed below. In the syntaxes ''given'', ''text'', ''name'', and section cannot contain the characters '/' and '|'; and any '<' or '>' should be matched. :*; L : Link to a Perl manual page (e.g., L). Note that name should not contain spaces. This syntax is also occasionally used for references to UNIX man pages : E.g L. :*; L or L : Link to a section in other manual page. :: E.g. L :: L or L or L<"sec"> : Link to a section in this manual page. E.g., :: L A section is started by the named heading or item. For example, C> or C> both link to the section started by "C<=item $.>" in perlvar. And C> or C> both link to the section started by "C<=head2 For Loops>" in perlsyn. To control what text is used for display, you use "C>", as in: * L Link this text to that manual page. E.g., C> =item * C> or C> Link this text to that section in that manual page. E.g., C> =item * C> or C> or C> Link this text to that section in this manual page. E.g., C> =back Or you can link to a web page: =over =item * C> Links to an absolute URL. For example, C>. But note that there is no corresponding C> syntax, for various reasons. =back =item C> -- a character escape X X<< EZ<><> >> X X Very similar to HTML/XML C<&I;> "entity references": =over =item * C<<> -- a literal < (less than) =item * C<>> -- a literal > (greater than) =item * C> -- a literal | (Itical I) =item * C> = a literal / (Iidus) The above four are optional except in other formatting codes, notably C>, and when preceded by a capital letter. =item * C> Some non-numeric HTML entity name, such as C>, meaning the same thing as C<é> in HTML -- i.e., a lowercase e with an acute (/-shaped) accent. =item * C> The ASCII/Latin-1/Unicode character with that number. A leading "0x" means that I is hex, as in C>. A leading "0" means that I is octal, as in C>. Otherwise I is interpreted as being in decimal, as in C>. Note that older Pod formatters might not recognize octal or hex numeric escapes, and that many formatters cannot reliably render characters above 255. (Some formatters may even have to use compromised renderings of Latin-1 characters, like rendering C> as just a plain "e".) =back =item C> -- used for filenames X X<< FZ<><> >> X X Typically displayed in italics. Example: "C>" =item C> -- text contains non-breaking spaces X X<< SZ<><> >> X X This means that the words in I should not be broken across lines. Example: S>>. =item C> -- an index entry X X<< XZ<><> >> X X This is ignored by most formatters, but some may use it for building indexes. It always renders as empty-string. Example: C> =item C> -- a null (zero-effect) formatting code X X<< ZZ<><> >> X X This is rarely used. It's one way to get around using an E<...> code sometimes. For example, instead of "C" (for "N<3") you could write "C<3>" (the "Z<>" breaks up the "N" and the "<" so they can't be considered the part of a (fictitious) "N<...>" code. =for comment This was formerly explained as a "zero-width character". But it in most parser models, it parses to nothing at all, as opposed to parsing as if it were a E or E, which are REAL zero-width characters. So "width" and "character" are exactly the wrong words. =back Most of the time, you will need only a single set of angle brackets to delimit the beginning and end of formatting codes. However, sometimes you will want to put a real right angle bracket (a greater-than sign, '>') inside of a formatting code. This is particularly common when using a formatting code to provide a different font-type for a snippet of code. As with all things in Perl, there is more than one way to do it. One way is to simply escape the closing bracket using an C code: C<$a <=> $b> This will produce: "C<$a <=> $b>" A more readable, and perhaps more "plain" way is to use an alternate set of delimiters that doesn't require a single ">" to be escaped. With the Pod formatters that are standard starting with perl5.5.660, doubled angle brackets ("<<" and ">>") may be used I For example, the following will do the trick: X C<< $a <=> $b >> In fact, you can use as many repeated angle-brackets as you like so long as you have the same number of them in the opening and closing delimiters, and make sure that whitespace immediately follows the last '<' of the opening delimiter, and immediately precedes the first '>' of the closing delimiter. (The whitespace is ignored.) So the following will also work: X C<<< $a <=> $b >>> C<<<< $a <=> $b >>>> And they all mean exactly the same as this: C<$a <=> $b> As a further example, this means that if you wanted to put these bits of code in C (code) style: open(X, ">>thing.dat") || die $! $foo->bar(); you could do it like so: C<<< open(X, ">>thing.dat") || die $! >>> C<< $foo->bar(); >> which is presumably easier to read than the old way: C>thing.dat") || die $!> C<$foo->bar();> This is currently supported by pod2text (Pod::Text), pod2man (Pod::Man), and any other pod2xxx or Pod::Xxxx translators that use Pod::Parser 1.093 or later, or Pod::Tree 1.02 or later. == The Intent == X The intent is simplicity of use, not power of expression. Paragraphs look like paragraphs (block format), so that they stand out visually, and so that I could run them through C easily to reformat them (that's F7 in my version of B, or Esc Q in my version of B). I wanted the translator to always leave the C<'> and C<`> and C<"> quotes alone, in verbatim mode, so I could slurp in a working program, shift it over four spaces, and have it print out, er, verbatim. And presumably in a monospace font. The Pod format is not necessarily sufficient for writing a book. Pod is just meant to be an idiot-proof common source for nroff, HTML, TeX, and other markup languages, as used for online documentation. Translators exist for B, B, B (that's for nroff(1) and troff(1)), B, and B. Various others are available in CPAN. === Embedding Pods in Perl Modules === You can embed Pod documentation in your Perl modules and scripts. Start your documentation with an empty line, a "=head1" command at the beginning, and end it with a "=cut" command and an empty line. Perl will ignore the Pod text. See any of the supplied library modules for examples. If you're going to put your Pod at the end of the file, and you're using an __END__ or __DATA__ cut mark, make sure to put an empty line there before the first Pod command. __END__ =head1 NAME Time::Local - efficiently compute time from local and GMT time Without that empty line before the "=head1", many translators wouldn't have recognized the "=head1" as starting a Pod block. === Hints for Writing Pod === =over =item * The B command is provided for checking Pod syntax for errors and warnings. For example, it checks for completely blank lines in Pod blocks and for unknown commands and formatting codes. You should still also pass your document through one or more translators and proofread the result, or print out the result and proofread that. Some of the problems found may be bugs in the translators, which you may or may not wish to work around. =item * If you're more familiar with writing in HTML than with writing in Pod, you can try your hand at writing documentation in simple HTML, and converting it to Pod with the experimental L module, (available in CPAN), and looking at the resulting code. The experimental L module in CPAN might also be useful. =item * Many older Pod translators require the lines before every Pod command and after every Pod command (including "=cut"!) to be a blank line. Having something like this: # - - - - - - - - - - - - =item $firecracker->boom() This noisily detonates the firecracker object. =cut sub boom { ... ...will make such Pod translators completely fail to see the Pod block at all. Instead, have it like this: # - - - - - - - - - - - - * $firecracker->boom() ** This noisily detonates the firecracker object. sub boom { ... * Some older Pod translators require paragraphs (including command paragraphs like "=head2 Functions") to be separated by I empty lines. If you have an apparently empty line with some spaces on it, this might not count as a separator for those translators, and that could cause odd formatting. * Older translators might add wording around an L<> link, so that C> may become "the Foo::Bar manpage", for example. So you shouldn't write things like C documentation>, if you want the translated document to read sensibly -- instead write C documentation> or C>, to control how the link comes out. * Going past the 70th column in a verbatim block might be ungracefully wrapped by some formatters. == SEE ALSO == L, L, L, L, L, L, L. == AUTHOR == Larry Wall, Sean M. Burke =cut [[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

<noinclude> {{navigation|Book=Topology |current=Induced homomorphism |previous=The fundamental group |next=Simplicial complexes}} </noinclude>
The induced homomorphism is related to the study of the fundamental group. We will give a few theorems and notes, but first we make a definition.
'''Definition'''
Let X and Y be topological spaces; let x<sub>0</sub> be a point of X and let y<sub>0</sub> be a point of y. Suppose h is a continuous map from X to Y such that h(x<sub>0</sub>) = y<sub>0</sub>. Define a map h* from π<sub>1</sub>(X,x<sub>0</sub>) to π<sub>2</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>) by composing a loop in π<sub>1</sub>(X,x<sub>0</sub>) with h to get a loop in π<sub>1</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>). Then h* is a homomorphism between fundamental groups known as the homomorphism induced by h.
'''Note 1'''
Let us check that if f is a loop in π<sub>1</sub>(X,x<sub>0</sub>), then h*(f) is a loop in π<sub>1</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>). Note that h*(f) is a continuous map from [a,b] to Y (we will assume that [a,b] = [0,1] which has no difference to the general case since these two sets are homeomorphic), and h*(f(0)) = h*(x<sub>0</sub>) = y0 and h*(f(1)) = h*(x<sub>0</sub>) = y<sub>0</sub>.
'''Note 2'''
We will check that h is indeed a homomorphism. To avoid repetition, whenever we call f and g loops, they will be known as loops based at x<sub>0</sub>. Suppose f and g are two loops. Then [0 is the group operation on π<sub>1</sub>(X,x<sub>0</sub>) and + is the group operation on π<sub>1</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>)]
h*(f 0 g) = h*(f(2t)) for t in [0,1/2] = (h*(f)) + (h*(g))
h*(f 0 g) = h*(g(2t-1)) for t in [1/2,1] = (h*(f)) + (h*(g))
so that h* is indeed a homomorphism.
'''Note 3'''
Checking h* is a function (i.e, every loop in π<sub>1</sub>(X,x<sub>0</sub>) gets mapped onto a unique loop in π<sub>1</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>)) follows from the fact that if f and g are loops in π<sub>1</sub>(X,x0) that are homotopic via the homotopy H, then h*(f) and h*(g) are homotopic via the homotopy h*H.
'''Note 4'''
Note that none of the above notes would be true unless h is continuous which is why this is needed in the hypothesis. We leave it to you to work out why h(x<sub>0</sub>) = y<sub>0</sub> [which is fairly trivial].
We now prove one important theorem which can be used to check whether two topological spaces are homeomorphic or not. In fact, this theorem illustrates why algebraic topology was invented in the first place.
'''Theorem'''
Suppose X and Y are two homeomorphic topological spaces. If h is a homeomorphism from X to Y, then the induced homomorphism, h* is an isomorphism between fundamental groups [Assume that we are considering the fundamental groups π<sub>1</sub>(X,x<sub>0</sub>) and π<sub>1</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>) with h(x<sub>0</sub>) = y<sub>0</sub>]
'''Proof'''
We have already checked in note 2 that h* is a homomorphism. It remains to check that h* is bijective. Suppose p is the inverse of h; then p* is the inverse of h*. This follows from the fact that (p(h))*(f) = p*(h*(f)) = f = (h(p))*(f) = h*(p*(f)). If f and g are two loops in X where f is not homotopic to g, the h*(f) is not homotopic to h*(g); if F is a homotopy between them, p*(F) would be a homotopy between f and g. If k is any loop in π<sub>1</sub>(Y,y<sub>0</sub>) , then h*(p*(k)) = k where p*(k) is a loop in X. This shows that h* is bijective.
'''Note''': It is a good exercise to check that we used all the properties that h satisfies, i.e we used completely, the fact that h is a homeomorphism.
'''Applications of the Theorems'''
1. The torus is not homeomorphic to R^2 for their fundamental groups are not isomorphic (their fundamental groups don’t have the same cardinality). Note that, a simply connected space cannot be homeomorphic to a non-simply connected space; one has a trivial fundamental group and the other does not.
2. In fact, any two topological spaces have homomorphic fundamental groups (at a particular base point). See note 2 where we may let h* be the homomorphism induced by the constant map. However, they need not have isomorphic fundamental groups (at a particular base point). This is interesting because it shows that the fundamental groups of any two topological spaces always have the same ‘group structure’.
3. The fundamental group of the unit circle is isomorphic to the additive group of integers. Therefore, the fundamental group of [0,1] is isomorphic to the set of integers since [0,1] and the unit circle are homeomorphic (why is this statement false?). The one-point compactification of R also has a fundamental group isomorphic to the set of integers (since the one-point compactification of R is homeomorphic to the unit circle).
4. The converse of the theorem need not hold. For example, R^2 and R^3 have isomorphic fundamental groups but are still not homeomorphic. Their fundamental groups are isomorphic because each space is simply connected. However, the two spaces cannot be homeomorphic because deleting a point from R^2 leaves a non-simply connected space but deleting a point from R^3 leaves a simply connected space (If we delete a line lying in R^3, the space wouldn’t be simply connected anymore. In fact this generalizes to R^n whereby deleting a (n-2) dimensional parallelepiped from R^n leaves a non-simply connected space).
<noinclude> {{navigation|Book=Topology |current=Induced homomorphism |previous=The fundamental group |next=Simplicial complexes}}
{{BookCat}} </noinclude>

== Welcome! == Welcome, Dallas1278! {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |} Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.--'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 03:18, 12 June 2008 (UTC) == Doing Great Work! == I'm watching your progress on the RC feed, you're doing great work alphabetizing all those books. It's a real service to this project. Good job, and keep up the good work! --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 03:05, 14 July 2008 (UTC) :Hello Dallas. Welcome to wikibooks! Just to repeat what Whitknight has said: great work! I might try and do some categorising myself :-) --[[User:AdRiley|AdRiley]] ([[User talk:AdRiley|talk]]) 12:41, 14 July 2008 (UTC) == Don't do the "TeX/" books == Do me a favor and don't tag the rest of the "TeX/" books. Those need to be cleaned up in a different way. Thanks. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 02:32, 28 July 2008 (UTC) == [[WB:RIGHTS]] == Have you thought about doing other cleanup tasks? You've certainly been prolific with categorizing - would you be interested in doing [[WB:NPP|new page patrol]]?  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 16:19, 28 July 2008 (UTC) Hello Dallas! I am an instructor for a course at Old Dominion University. Our students write the wikibooks titled Foundations of Education and Instructional Assessment. You have been tampering with our pages and I am not sure why. I am not clear why you have put an {{Alphabetical|E}} on our page. We are required to post the Category button on all pages we create. Is there something I am missing? I would be more than happy to explain our project in more detail, if this would clear up the confusion. We also have students rate each others work. Is there something incorrect with our rating button coding? Thank you for your clarification! [[User:Jkauf007|Jkauf007]] ([[User talk:Jkauf007|talk]]) 01:52, 26 August 2008 (UTC) Hello Dallas, Each semester we build a new edition to our book. Students sign up to write the articles, but sometimes there are a few empty pages. We place category buttons on these so that they are no tampered with or erased. This also allows visitors from outside of the class to contribute to our book. Currently we are building the third edition. Unfortunately, with all of our responsibilities, we can not build over a thousand pages in a day. We would appreciate your hesitation in marking blank pages (those without category buttons) because we are on a mission to finish them ASAP. We really appreciate your assitance to the Wikibook project and please feel free to send me a message if you have any questions and/or before you mark a lot of pages. This will save both of us time. Have a great day! [[User:Jkauf007|Jkauf007]] ([[User talk:Jkauf007|talk]]) 21:17, 26 August 2008 (UTC)

== Join Us! == {{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or logging in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, as your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone else's. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have been edited. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time, especially given the benefits. We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|
'''This template must only be used on User talk pages.'''
}}--'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 03:32, 12 June 2008 (UTC)
